Ideal:
- Fungible
- Universal 
- Scalable
- Permissionless
- Reliable

Reality:
- Pseudoanonymous
- Underdeveloped Wallets
- Layering in Beta
- Mining Economies of Scale
- Minimal Tor Nodes, Unencrypted

Keep the ideals in mind, the current reality is not the destination.

973954753867714561.text: 9/ Their guidelines dont cover how a token might be classified post-ICO: e.g. when they are trading on an exchange. They understand that tokens can change over time.  Mostly concerned with facts at the time of ICO. Less interested in "intent"; seems to differs w/ USA.

973953680553672704.text: 8/ FINMA stated they have done deep legal analysis. However, stressed that these are not an end-point. Definitions can evolve / change. Tokens may change their type over time. Note their guidelines only pertain to the ICO phase: i.e. the fundraising phase.

973953161236017152.text:
7/ Roughly: 
Payment - a means of payment (cryptocurrencies). Not generally issued through ICOs.
Asset - represents an asset: eg. debt, equity.
Utility - provides digital access to an application or service by means of a blockchain-based infrastructure at the point of issue.pic.twitter.com/IpkXhpQrUk

973952332328329216.text: 6/ The main section of their presentation recapped the 3 ICO categories: payment tokens, asset tokens, utility tokens. Again, see their publication: https://www.finma.ch/en/news/2018/02/20180216-mm-ico-wegleitung/ …pic.twitter.com/dJqKYWRl1s

973951894438731776.text: 5/ They were keen to show off a couple of 'wins', including their ICO guidelines and the creation of a working group within the Federal Government of Switzerland.pic.twitter.com/RzcEGV3Gho

973951366266843136.text: 4/ They push for removal of unnecessary regulatory obstacles for innovative business models. No unnecessary obstacles, but no tolerance of criminal behaviour. Principle based, technology-neutral and competition-neutral regulation and supervision.pic.twitter.com/U0IcHJjDVk
